results.title: Fences
results.brief_description: Early colonial settlers ran sheep on huge unenclosed areas of grazing lands, but when gold was discovered shepherds left the sheep-runs and flocked to the gold-fields. Sheep were “enclosed” and later fences were erected as protection against rabbits and wild dogs.

results.title: Femmes de Personne = Nobody's Women
results.brief_description:
Isabelle, Adeline and Cecile work in a radiology practice. Disappointed by relationships with men, they content themselves with chance encounters. In this indulgent piece on mid-life crisis in the middle classe, the male characters are presented as a collection of irresponsible, self-centred creatures while women battle to come to term with the great decisions in life such as child bearing and rearing, with force booze and cigarettes for solace.

Credits: Producer, Alain Terzian ; director, Christopher Frank ; writer, Christopher Frank ; photography, Jean Tournier ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Marthe Keller, Jean-Louis Trintignant, Caroline Cellier, Fanny Cottencon, Philippe Leotard.

results.title: Femme fatale [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Quinta Communications, Tarak Ben Ammar, Marina Gefter and Brian De Palma
results.brief_description: Brian de Palma’s exciting and kinetic celebration of cinema has a frankly ludicrous plot involving diamond smugglers, a violent, beautiful and ruthless lesbian anti-heroine, and an audaciously over-the-top climax. But none of that matters for this strikingly shot film, beginning at the actual 2001 Cannes Film Festival and culminating in a breathlessly executed finale on the streets of Paris, is a joyful celebration of the possibilities of action cinema. De Palma has always been one of Hitchcock’s staunchest heirs and “Femme fatale” is a continuation of that master’s pleasure in creating a virtuoso cinema of spectacle, technique and purely cinematic language. From the sharpness of Bill Pankow’s editing to the sublime use of split-screen and subjective camera, from the clever pastiche of Ryuichi Sakamoto’s score to the crisp cinematography of Theirry Arbogast, “Femme fatale” is a film in love with cinema itself. Rebecca Romijn-Stamos makes for a suitably sexy and dangerous noir heroine; Antonio Banderas is the mug who falls in love with her; and there are guest cameos by Cannes Film Festival director, Gilles Jacob, by French director Regis Wargnier and French actress, Sandrine Bonnaire.

results.title: Feminine Fashions in India
results.creator_credit: Ezra Mir, Films Division, Government of India and Dilip Jamdar
results.brief_description: Presents the colorful costumes worn by women of India as their daily dress. The sari is the most commonly worn style, others shown include the Rajasthani ghagra, bodice and odhani, salvar kamiz and dupatta of Punjab and garara of Uttar Pradesh.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ezra Mir, Films Division, Government of India and Dilip Jamdar

results.title: Feminine fashions
results.creator_credit: M. Bhavnani, Documentary Films of India and K Khandpur
results.brief_description: The costumes of Indian women and the accessories that go with them. The sari, the most popular dress, and also the pheran of Kashmiri women, the colorful dresses of the Khasi and Naga women of Assam, the salwar and kameez of the Punjab and the gharara and odhuni worn by the young women from Uttar Pradesh.

results.title: Female cycle
results.brief_description: A simple animated explanation of menstruation. It shows how ovaries produce eggs, one of which moves to the surface each month and enters the fallopian tube to travel to the uterus. Secretions from these organs enter the blood and prepare the uterus for the fertilised egg and cause a period.

results.title: Fellow Traveller
results.creator_credit: Michael Wearing, BBC Film Unit, Home Box Office, BFI and Philip Saville
results.brief_description: A leading American screenwriter arrives in London in the mid-50’s to make a new life. Back in Hollywood, a famous movie star shoots himself. The link between these involves a girl and a history - that of the McCarthy witch hunts and the careers they destroyed. Asa Kaufman (Ron Silver) finds work writing a Robin Hood serial in the eccentric world of Britain’s new ITV, but he can’t escape the psychic and political pressures that drove him into exile. With Daniel J. Travanti.

results.title: Fellini: the director as creator
results.creator_credit: Harold Mantell, Radiotelevisione Italiana and Fulco Film
results.brief_description: This short film on the late, great, Italian film director was the first time motion picture cameras were permitted on the set to reveal his creative process. Harold Mantell’s documentary uses footage shot behind the scenes and on the sets of of Fellini’s film “Juliet of the Spirits” (1965) (304304) as a canvas to talk about this acclaimed director. The film shows the magnificent film sets, Fellini’s character people (whose faces were invented for his films), the relationship with his actor/wife Guilietta Masina, and the cast and crew. The film also features his techniques of improvisation and interview material. “Juliet of the Spirits” is held in the Collection on VHS. While the film is crammed with interesting facts about Fellini, the man and creative artist, it is not intended as a guide to his body of work. Another documentary in the Collection on VHS, “Ciao Frederico: A Portrait Of Frederico Fellini,” was also made during the shooting of “Satyricon”.

results.title: Fell
results.brief_description: This experimental puppet animation has an uneasy feel reminiscent of videos made in the 90’s by Tool guitarist Adam Jones. A small wooden figure tries to stand unassisted on trembling limbs as nameless shadows flicker just out of sight. “Fell” was an outstanding contribution to the 2000 Diegesis Program. It is a surreal and beautiful work.
